supporting.text: Donald Trump was born in Queens, New York, which is part of the United States, making him an American by birthright.

attacks.text: Donald Trump was born in Queens, New York, which is part of the United States, making him an American by birthright.
Birthright citizenship has been historically contested, and some legal scholars argue it does not automatically confer nationality in all cases.
There are unverified claims that Donald Trump's birth records may have been falsified, casting doubt on his place of birth.
The 14th Amendment of the U.S. Constitution explicitly guarantees birthright citizenship, leaving no legal ambiguity for those born on U.S. soil.
No credible evidence has ever been presented to support the claim that Trump's birth records were falsified.
Historical court rulings have consistently upheld the interpretation of the 14th Amendment as granting citizenship to all born on U.S. soil, regardless of parental status.

supporting.text: Donald Trump holds U.S. citizenship and has never renounced it, legally affirming his status as an American.

attacks.text: Donald Trump holds U.S. citizenship and has never renounced it, legally affirming his status as an American.
Legal citizenship does not necessarily equate to cultural or social acceptance as an American by all segments of society.
There have been allegations of fraudulent activities in Trump's past that could potentially affect his legal standing, including citizenship.
Cultural and social acceptance are subjective and do not negate legal citizenship status.
No legal proceedings have ever substantiated claims of fraudulent activities affecting Trump's citizenship.
Subjective perceptions can influence legal interpretations and societal recognition, which are important in defining national identity.

supporting.text: Trump has served as the 45th President of the United States, a role constitutionally restricted to natural-born U.S. citizens, further confirming his American identity.

attacks.text: Trump has served as the 45th President of the United States, a role constitutionally restricted to natural-born U.S. citizens, further confirming his American identity.
The constitutional requirement for natural-born citizenship has been subject to legal disputes and interpretations that may not universally confirm Trump's eligibility.
Holding the presidency does not inherently prove natural-born citizenship, as historical records or legal exceptions could complicate the matter.
Legal precedents and Supreme Court rulings have consistently upheld the natural-born citizenship requirement, leaving no ambiguity for Trump's case.
Trump's birth certificate and public records conclusively demonstrate his natural-born citizenship, negating any doubts about his eligibility.
Some legal scholars argue that the term 'natural-born citizen' is not explicitly defined in the Constitution, leaving room for interpretation.
Historical instances of presidential candidates facing citizenship challenges indicate that eligibility is not always straightforward.
Birth certificates can be subject to fraud or errors, casting doubt on their absolute reliability as proof of citizenship.
